Another interesting observation : When the masses colliding are powers of some other base (say 3), the number of collisions still equal the digits of Pi, but in the same base.
Eg : Pi in base 3 is 10.010211012222010211002111110221222220111201212121...

If you run the simulation with masses of 1, 3^(2 * 1), 3^(2 * 2), 3^(2 * 3),..., then the number of collisions will be 1 (base 3), 10 (base 3), 100 (base 3), and 1001 (base 3) respectively.

Number of collisions for 1,3^(2 * 50) will be first 50 digits of Pi in base 3 : 10010211012222010211002111110221222220111201212121 , or 2255343044159619899886237 in decimals.

Assume there is a floor and a wall. There is a 1 lkg box on the left and a box to its right as shown in the diagram. Assume there is no friction and that no energy is lost during any collision. Set the right box to 1 kg and cause it to move to the left until it collides with the 1 kg box. It stops and the left box is pushed to the wall where it bounces off, collides with the right box and stops. The right box travels off to the right. Count the total number of collisions: there are 3. Repeat by setting the right box to 100 kg; 10,000 kg; 1,000,000 kg ..., etc. We have: Set the right box to 1 kg and count the collisions: there are 3 Set the right box to 100 kg and count the collisions: there are 31 Set the right box to 10,000 kg and count the collisions: there are 314 Set the right box to 1,000,000 kg and count the collisions: there are 3141 Each time you increase the right box by 100x, you generate an additional digit of pi. /

When the larger block reaches a certain multiple (size wise) of the smaller block, then that larger block will eventually have a mass that is large enough to generate a gravity field that is strong enough to affect the motion of the smaller block, resulting in the smaller block having fewer collisions.

To put it another way...
When the large block's gravity reaches a certain point, it will no longer push the smaller block hard enough for the smaller block to continue in the opposite direction. The smaller block will become gravity attached to the larger block.

But I understand the point of the video, which takes place in a friction-less and gravity-less environment, and how those conditions relate to pi.

Perhaps you could set up analogous situations for any other base:

0. You have two blocks with masses of 1 and b^2^(d-1), where b is the base of the number system and d is the number of digits in that base you want to compute.

1. Count the number of collisions in that base.

2. You now have an approximation of pi*b^(d-1) in that base.

Also this is very similar to when i tried to simulate electrons in GMS. When i tried to put in about 100+(about 124?) The engine was like "Ehh, fck the rules!" and threw out 1 electron of the orbit, even though in the programming it was set as the electron is pulled in x Gravity(I used gravity because it is the easiest way to simulate acceleration and decalartion along with speed, if i just choose speed it wouldn't have been effective.) AND when it is further than 300 units from the middle object(the nucleus) it was told to stay within limits with it's gravitational push.(Because electrons don't like eachother, they are trying to get away from eachother to reach energy minimum) so when i applied this "gravitational push" what got into my mind "okay this simulates electrons to f14 well enough, now what if i tried put in enormous amounts of them?"
I put in about 50 then 100 then 150 and even at 150 it pushed out some. and then at about 124 it pushed out the others too.
After i changed my method on the programming the push out stopped, BUT they stayed in the middle.... covering the nucleus... Which states that if i were to follow my old method it would've been pushed out, but instead it just got to the middle and stayed on top of the nucleus(which means it was in front of it) but since the sizes determined how far they were from eachother all i could say about this is that... yes... it should've been pretty big if I didn't set a limit to how big they get.

That is beautiful. I love random mathematical rules that show up in completely absurd places. One of my favorite is the kids toy version of The Tower of Hanoi where you have n plastic donuts and three poles to move them around on. The goal is to move the stack from one pole to another while only moving one at a time and only putting a smaller donut on a larger one. The number of moves required to move the entire stack is 2^n - 1, the same as the binary function for computing the number of available TCP/IP addresses in a subnet in binary math. There's a Linux screensaver version, GL Hanoi, that has a simple animation of the process I spent way too many hours watching but it's so satisfying!

I'm confused: you say that  100^(20-1) equals 100 billion billion billion billion, but if I counted the zeros correctly, that's wrong:

100^(20-1) = 10^38
100 billion billion billion billion = 10^50

(Remember: the mathematical definition of a billion means "million squared" (bi = 2), which is 10^12. Similarly a trillion is a "million to the power of 3" (tri = 3), which is 10^18. And so on. Some people, especially Americans, always seem to get this wrong...)

(BTW: the prefix "bi" for "two" is used in the same way in several other terms, like "biquadractic equation", which is the square of a quadratic equation. Or "bifurcation point", which is a point where the solutions of a differential equation diverge into two different directions, etc.)

1/2mv^2

Hmm. The equation of a circle is of the form

x^2 + y^2 = const

Well, we know that (for the system of two masses)

m1v1^2 + m2v2^2 = 2*const = const

Remember, an arbitrary number times a constant is still an arbitrary number.

So, we have an x and a y. Now, where does pi fit in?

Let’s say the x is the energy of the larger box. Remember how it had to be a power of 100? That’s 10^2. So we know that

sqrt(m1) = integer

Since we’re setting m2 to 1 kilogram, that’s also simple to explain. Let’s loot at our new equation.

m1v1^2 + v2^2 = const

It’s at this point we are hit over the head with a simple realization: this is an ellipse. If you haven’t figured it out yet, the extra constant should explain itself. So, what now?

v1^2/const + v2^2/(m1*const) = 1

Divide by all constants and you get the standard equation for an ellipse. The center is at (0, 0), major axis sqrt(m1 * const), semi major axis sqrt(const), and foci at (0, sqrt(const*(m1 – 1))) and (0, -sqrt(const*(m1 – 1))). Pi doesn’t come in until either an area or circumference is concerned, so let’s look at that next. The area is a far simpler equation, so we’ll start there.

A = pi*a*b

Substitute our variables.

A = pi*sqrt(m1)*const

Aha! We’re getting somewhere! Now we just need to relate the area to something. But it’s now I realize one crucial fact: const can literally be any non-zero number. No matter how fast the first box is moving, it’s going to yield the same results. So set it equal to 1.

A = pi*sqrt(m1)

I’m getting a feeling that the area will be the number of clacks. But why is that so? First, we acknowledge that it fits reality. It just does. But I don’t know why it fits.

If you consider the velocity of both blocks as functions of the number of collisions happened, say v1(k) and v2(k), and plug in conservation of momentum and conservation of mass, then it follows that v1(k) and v2(k) are described by a linear difference equation with a closed form solution. Evaluate the solution after even number of collisions, stop counting after the velocity of the heavier block is positive (in right direction) and the (absolute) velocity of the less heavy block is smaller than the 8absolute) velocity of the heavier block. The solution has the form  v1(k) =Asin(wk+phi), v2(k) =Bsin(wk+psii), so from here on it is not surprising that pi appears somewhere later.

At mass ratio approaching infinity, the situation becomes entirely symmetrical. The large mass M arrives at velocity V, transfer momentum to the wall through the smaller mass (1 in my calculations), then leaves at velocity -V leaving the smaller mass standing still. If the smaller mass didn't exist, the entirety of the momentum transfer would have occurred in one collision, but here the smaller mass facilitates the transfer in many small collisions. If the momentum of the entire system is considered along with the momentum of the second mass, their trajectory forms half an ellipse, with M^0.5 being the ratio between the long and short axes.
If this ellipse is transformed to a half-circle by a transformation v`2 = M^0.5*v2, its radius is M, so that its circumference is pi*M^2, and this is where I run out of time, need to get back to work.

#include <iostream>
#include <vector>

int main() {

const float V = 1;
const float Ma = 0.01;
const float Mb = 1000000;

std::vector<float> Va = { 0 };
std::vector<float> Vb = { V };

float totalMomentum = Mb * Vb[0] + Ma * Va[0];

Vb.push_back((Mb-Ma)* V / (Mb+Ma));
Va.push_back(Vb[1] + V);

totalMomentum = Mb * Vb[1] - Ma * Va[1];

int i = 2;
int collisions = 0;
while (Vb[i - 1]<Va[i-1]) {
Va.push_back ((totalMomentum/Ma + Mb*(Vb[i - 1] + Va[i - 1])/Ma) / (Mb/Ma+1));
Vb.push_back ((totalMomentum/Ma - Va[i - 1] - Vb[i - 1]) / (Mb / Ma - 1));
totalMomentum = Mb * Vb[i] - Ma * Va[i];
i++;
collisions++;
}

collisions = 2 * collisions -1;
std::cout << collisions << std::endl;

system("pause");
}

Okay... I have a proof which works, provided that there is no point in the decimal expansion of pi where the second half of the decimals up to that point are all 9's; which is true for pi as far as we know it, but I don't think there's an actual proof of that.

In other words; it works when ceiling(10^(d-1)*pi)-10^(d-1)*pi > 10^(-d) for all d. I don't think that's something we know, except for up to very high but finite numbers d.

Edit: in my original post I talked about 0's, not 9's. That's because I mistakenly took my under-estimation to be an over-estimation.

In Summer 2011, I was given this problem by my calculus teacher without any reference to the original work by Galperin (but later on he showed me that work). He asked if I can find a hidden circle in this surprising solution. After spending 2 sleepless days, I finally ended up with a 3.5-page explanation, describing that pi arises from an area of an ellipse that itself contains phase states of the system in velocity space (v1, v2). Unfortunately, at the moment I do not have enough time to make a translation, but still I shared that text on overleaf: overleaf.com/read/rxwcjchtmqqn. Hope the idea might be comprehensible from formulas and figures only. I considered there more general case for mass ratio of m1/m2 = b^{2n}, where b is the base.

The main point is that as far as I am aware, the fact that the number of collisions follows the decimal notation of pi is not yet proven (and possibly might not be). In addition, there are seemingly infinite number of explicit exceptions in different bases, e.g. 6, 7, 14, 21, 113, etc. (see text). And there is no evidence that base 10 is somehow special in this sense. At this time I am not sure, but the exception in base 10 requires something like 2n consecutive nines after n-th position in decimal notation of pi. Which seems weird, but still not impossible.

So, this is what I managed to solve:

Let's consider the sequence x_n = the total number of collisions in the system where the heavier body is 100^n times heavier. Using some matrix algebra, polynomials, complex numbers and trigonometry, I found that x_n is aproximatley equal to 2*pi / arcsin(2*10^n/10^2n + 1).
Computing the limit L = lim x_n / 10^n (which is essentially what the video is asking for), I found that L is exactley pi.
Maybe this can't explain why the number of collisions follows this exact pattern in the video, but at least it's something. :)

If you want to know more about how I managed to find the form for x_n, please let me know in the coments.

Ohhhhh, I get why this problem counts to a particular digit. The problem defines ending momenta for the masses where there's some uncertainty on the small momentum (must be greater than or equal to 0 but less than a certain fraction of the larger momentum) where the degree of relative uncertainty reduces as the big mass gets bigger. So it's basically a way too complicated single collision calculation with some of the values artificially given uncertainty to make the calculation of finite precision. Neat!

Solved :D

The circle in question is a circle in the momentum phase space. Specifically say m2 is the heavier block, if you rescale the momentum variable p1 and p2 by sqrt{m}, then you have a very nice circle equation. The entire process amounts to turning by angle pi from the point (p1,p2)=(0,1) to (0,-1) so that the heavier block is reflected.

Every collision between the two blocks can be written down as a mapping between points on the circle in the phase space(ie old momentum determining new momentum completely, while obeying energy conservation so staying on the circle). Every collision at the wall serves to reflect the point about the p2 axis so that the direction of p1 is flipped. Every step leaves a point on the circle, and each point corresponds to a click sound. So the total number of points on the circle(minus the starting point) is the same as the total number of clicks heard.

Since all collisions between two blocks is followed by a collision at the wall, we can consider these two events forming a single step. It turns out that as the ratio r=m1/m2 gets smaller, this step approaches an infinitesimal rotation generator, with each step’s rotation angle being 2sqrt{r}. If we let k to be the number of rotation steps to execute the full pi angle rotation from (1,0) to (0,1), then 2sqrt{r}=\pi/k, or 2k=\pi/\sqrt{r}. We identify 2k as the total number of points on the circle(involving both the rotation and the reflection, thats why there’s a factor of 2), then if sqrt{r} is 10^-2n, we have 2k=\pi * 10^n, which is exactly what we have.

Here's an outline of a proof: Set the total energy of the system to 1 and the masses m1=m2. If we eliminate all equal factors, we get v1^2+v2^2=1. That happens to be the equation for the unit circle. To put it in another way, the solution can be thought of as a vector (v1, v2) satisfies the equation above only for points on the unit circle. Let's call that vector V for simplicity. For equal weights and a situation where v1=1, v2=0 at t=0, we get the following three events. Initially V=(1,0), at the first bounce, all energy is transfered to the particle p2, so V=(0,1). FInally all energy is transferred back to p1, so V=(-1,0). If we plot these solutions on the unit circle, we'll see that the vector completes half a turn around the circle, or pi radians. So there's our pi! But what if m1 != m2? We can fix that by squishing or stretching one of the axes. In other words, we transform to a new coordinate system where the world looks as if the masses were equal. Let's call the squishification factor c. From the equation of the ellipse, we can scale one of the velocities (say, v1) c, such that v1'=v1*sqrt(m2/m1), or c=sqrt(m2/m1). This follows from the equation of the ellipse. Using this coordinate transformation, we can still pretend that the masses are equal and get valid solutions in our new, transformed coordinate system. The side effect of this factor is that it also grows the radius (and thereby circumference) of the unit circle by c in the transformed coordinate system. This means that if c is an even power of 10, the circumference traced out by the bounces will be pi multiplied by a power of ten. We're almost there. Let's set r = m2/m1. Then c=sqrt(r). So if r is an even power of 100, the result of the square root must be an even power of ten, which makes us trace out pi*10^n, which gives some decimals of pi as an integer. I wasn't able to find a circle per se, but I was able to find an ellipse. First thing I did was write a program that counts the number of collisions.
count[m_] := Module[{u1, u2, n},
u1 = 0;
u2 = -1.;
n = 0;
While[True,
If[u1 < 0, u1 = -u1; n += 1];
If[u1 < u2, Break[]];
{u1, u2} = {(1 - m)/(1 + m)*u1 + (2 m)/(1 + m)*u2,
2/(1 + m)*u1 + (m - 1)/(1 + m)*u2};
n += 1];
Return[n]]

Then I plotted count[m] and found that it was roughly equal to Pi*Sqrt[m]±1. In the limit as m->infinity, it will always be the Pi*Sqrt[m] rounded down to the nearest integer.

I then messed around creating lists involving the momentum and the kinetic energy after each of the collisions. Mostly created parabolas which are neat but not useful at this time. Finally I created this code which generates a list of the velocities after each collision:
vpair[m_] := Module[{u1, u2, l},
u1 = 0;
u2 = -1;
l = {{u2, u1}};
While[True,
If[u1 < 0, u1 = -u1; l = Append[l, {u2, u1}];];
If[u1 < u2, Break[]];
{u1, u2} = {(1 - m)/(1 + m)*u1 + (2 m)/(1 + m)*u2,
2/(1 + m)*u1 + (m - 1)/(1 + m)*u2};
l = Append[l, {u2, u1}];];
Return[l]]

If you plot the data generate by vpair[m] (assuming m is greater than 1), it creates an ellipse with semi minor axis 1 and semi major axis Sqrt[m]. The area of an ellipse is Pi*a*b, so the number of collisions is approximately equal to the area of this ellipse.

Here is what I have so far: -
Energy is conserved so, no matter what any point of time we have m1*v1*v1 + m2*v2*v2 = m1*u*u (cancelling out facto of half and if we substitute m2=1kg)
v1*v1 + M*v2*v2= M*u*u
This is equation of ellipse with special case of M=1 when it becomes a circle. All the points on eclipse represent velocity of the blocks.

(y^2)/M + (x^2) = k ,constant
Here x --> velocity of block of mass M kg
y --> velocity of block of mass 1 kg


With some more physics we can conclude that every odd collision will be between two blocks and every even collision will be between smaller block and wall.
For block-block collision momentum is conserved and velocity is transferred from heavier to lighter block.
M*u = M*x1 + 1*y1
M = (y1 - 0)/(u-x1)
so (x1,y1) is a point on ellipse such that chord joining it to (u,0) makes an angle θ where tan(θ) = M (constant)

For block-wall collision momentum is NOT conserved and rather it changes direction but has same magnitude. So, system with velocities (xi,yi) becomes (xi,-yi)

So if we start from point (u,0) on right most extreme point on ellipse after collision 1 we end up at a point (x1,y1) as explained above
then after second collision we reach (x1,-y1) and this process is repeated till we reach the left most extreme point of ellipse.
And yes we will definitely reach point (-u,0) as the after the collision the first black with same velocity with which it came in as energy remains conserved.

Count(Collisions) = Count(Instersection points on ellipse) which using symmetry = 2*count(intersection points on upper half of ellipse) + 1 (the final point (-u,0))

I'd say that the answer is revealed in how you generated the sound. The bouncing, disregarding other factors, can be described as a simple sine wave. From that continuous function--though variable with respect to time--one can extract pi.

The first block starts by going left, having 100% of the momentum of the system. The clacks continue until that block is going right with all (or almost all) of the total momentum in the system. So you could plot this on a 2d chart. Let the X axis be the momentum of block 1 and the y axis is the momentum of block 2. If we take momentum to the right to be positive, the plot over time will start at (-1, 0) and end up at (1, 0).

Ok, here is what I've got let d1, d2 , v1, v2 and T be functions for the position (the wall is at 0 and positives to the right as usual), velocity (going to the left is negative and right is positive),and the time elapsed from the previous collision of the two masses in terms of the number of collisions that have occurred where the numbers indicate which block they belong to (let m1 be the 1kg block) we get a recurrence relation where :

(At every even collision the smaller block will hit the wall, we also calculate the position of the other block)

d1(n) = 0 for even n , d2(n) = d2(n-1) + v2(n-1) T(n) for odd n
d1(n) = v1(n-1) T(n) for even n, d2(n) = d2(n-1) + v2(n-1) T(n) for odd n

(Velocity is just turned negative once it hits the wall and we use the formula if it hits the other block)

v1(n) = - v1(n-1) for even n , v1(n) = ((m1-m2)v1(n-1) + 2(m2)(v2(n-1))/(m1+m2) for odd n
v2(n) = v2(n-1) for even n , v2(n) = ((m2-m1)v2(n-1) + 2(m1)(v1(n-1))/(m1+m2) for odd n

(Collision happens when either the 1kg block hits the wall or when the blocks collide)

T(n) = d1(n-1) / v1(n-1) for even n , T(n) = |d2(n-1) - d1(n-1))|/|v1(n-1)| + |v2(n-1)| for odd n
with v1(0) = 0, v2(0) = v_0, d1(1) = d_0, d2(1) = d_0

Also m2 begins to go right when v2(n+1) > 0 which is equivalent to 2(m1)(v1(n)/(m1-m2) > v2

I thought about this today and came up with a pretty rough explanation of why this happens. Can't wait to see 3b1b put it a lot more elegantly, though.

Basically my first thought was to find which values for the initially-moving cube's mass corresponded with a jump in the number of collisions. I wrote some code and used a few other tricks to help me find the pattern. Here's a bit of what my program spits out:

0.0 : 2
0.3333333333333333 : 3
1.0 : 4
1.8944271909999157 : 5
3.0 : 6
4.311941110422726 : 7
5.82842712474619 : 8
7.548632170413038 : 9
9.472135954999573 : 10
...

And that's basically saying, if the mass of the moving cube is more than the left number (but less than or equal to the next left number) the number on the right is the number of collisions you'd expect. So for example, if the mass is 1.5, we look at these two lines:

1.0 : 4
1.8944271909999157 : 5

...and since 1.5 is more than 1.0 but less than 1.8944271909999157, there will be 4 collisions.

The key was figuring out that the function that describes these values is cot(pi/N)^2. So, if the mass is greater than cot(pi/N)^2, but less than or equal to cot(pi/(N+1))^2, there will be N collisions. So for example, cot(pi/5)^2 = 1.8944271909999157..., which fits with the list I showed you above.

Messing around, you can find that when k is some integer and N is floor(10^k * pi), cot(pi/N)^2 is just under 10^(2k), and when N is 1 + floor(10^k * pi), cot(pi/N)^2 is just over 10^(2k). So whenever we have a mass of 10^(2k), we should get N = floor(10^k * pi) bounces, which is just the first k+1 digits of pi.

I didn't find a neat geometric way to observe a circle hidden in this problem, but it becomes a little more obvious that the circle is in there somewhere once you see that the function behind all this is cot(pi/N)^2. Can't wait for 3b1b's video on this!

I might not know the solution yet, BUT I have an INTERESTING analogy of this question. There is a different way to look at this problem. Assume the velocity with which the initial block was approaching to be 1m/s. We are assuming the velocity cause this initial velocity will only have a scaling effect on the size of the ellipse only. Now, the ellipse about which I just said comes from the energy conservation equations, which will be m_1v1^2 + m_2v2^2 = m_2, just said assuming initial velocity is 1m/s and I just removed the 1/2s from all side. Now we got an ellipse with major axis = sqrt(m_2/m_1) and minor axis = 1. We can consider this ellipse as an energy ellipse, cause for this system to work, all the collisions must occur on the ellipse. Now from the conservation of linear momentum, we got an equation of a line, m_1v_1 + m_2*v_2 = m_2, if we draw this line of slope -m_1/m_2 on the ellipse, we would get two points of intersections, (0,v) & (v_11, v_21), out of which one is the initial state and one is the "after collision among themselves" state, AND, from that state the second collision with the wall takes place, which changes the sign of the velocity of m_1, which gives rise to a 3rd state on the energy ellipse which would be (-v_11,v_21) state, then again a line of slope -m_1/m_2 is made to get the 4th point on the ellipse. And this process continues until we reach the bottom most part of the ellipse, cause after that, the m_1 and m_2 won't meet. Now if draw the lines inside the ellipses, joining the lines with respect to the events, (0,v) ---collision1--> (v_11,v_21) ---collision2--> (-v_11,v_21) and continue then the number of lines we are getting are nothing but equals to the total number of collisions. And for this case, its auxiliary equation being = pi*sqrt(m_2/m_1).

1.CONSERVATION OF ENERGY

As a lot of comment here, the conservation of energy equation( mv^2/2 + MV^2/2 = cte) remember the equation of ellipse (x^2/a^2 + y^2/b^2 = 1), maybe the circle we need is here...

the energy in the beginning is E = Mx^2/2 (x = inicial velocity ), and at any time, E' = mv'^2/2 + MV'^2/2. E=E' => Mx^2/2 = mv'^2/2 + MV'^2/2.

In the video, he talks about the ratio between the masses, so let M = km.

we get kmx^2/2 = mv'^2/2 + kmV'^2/2. Dividing both sides by m/2 : kx^2 = v'^2 + kV'^2. Dividing now by kx^2 we have: (v'^2)/(kx^2) + (V'^2)/x^2 = 1. (Ellipse!! :D )

now, in a 2d plane, with the x axis representing V, and y axis v (arbitrary), we have a ellipse, that the dots represent possible combinations of V and v, that keeps the energy constant. (Semi axis x) = x, (semi axis y) = x sqrt(k).

Ok, now we need to look at the conservation of momentum(Q) : MV + mv = MV' + mv' => Q = kV + v = KV' + v'.
In the plane described before, this equation represents a line, that crosses the Y axis on Q, and the ellipse on (V,v) and (V',v'). This means that for any shock between the blocks , we need to draw a line that cross Q on y axis, and (V,v), and the other point that this line crosses the ellipse will represent the new velocities!

when the block toutches the wall, v is multiplied by -1, graphically, it is turned up/down around the x axis.

We know that ends when the big block is faster than the other one (to the right), it will happen in the points below the line y = x, for x >0

with this, we can (graphically) predict the shocks!!!

Fascinating! After thinking about it for a bit, one might feel that the system is analogous to a simple harmonic oscillator:

1: Energy in small block is proportional to the square of the speed of the small block, analogous to how potential energy in a spring is proportional to the square of the displacement.

2: Energy in large block is proportional to the square of the speed of the large block, analogous to how kinetic energy of a mass is proportional to the square of the speed.

3: Momentum transfer per collision is proportional to the speed of the small block, analogous to to how momentum transfer per unit time is proportional to the displacement.

4: Total energy in system remains the same, analogous to, well...

Hence, by analogy to a simple harmonic oscillator, with
mass = large block mass, spring constant = small block mass, time = number of collisions:

Collisions for large block to reverse velocity
= time for mass in analogous SHO to reverse velocity
= half period of analogous SHO
= pi*sqrt(large mass/small mass)

Hence the mysterious appearance of pi in decimal (if large mass is some power of 100 times the small mass)

As I write the rest of this, I have now just spent a good hour or two writing up a script in matlab to simulate this, it does appear the levels of kinetic energy approach a cosine curve as the ratio of weight approaches infinity. I've graphed my results of different ratios of weights here: https://imgur.com/a/9q0IAD8

Doing trapezoidal integration on the data that makes up the curve, then dividing by the peak value, then dividing again by the number of collisions, the area underneath the cos curve is always 0.5. Which makes sense I guess, integrating from 0 to pi of (cos(x)+0.5)dx then dividing by that interval, gives the average value of 0.5.

The fact that we're using discrete collisions to calculate this means we're just doing a Riemann approximation of the integral of this function. As for why the ratio of weights needs to be 100^n, I have a feeling it has to do with the fact that the square root of 100 is 10, so we will get a value that is a power of 10 times pi and a power of 10 times the amplitude.

I took a while to ponder why this is, and I believe that the circle emanates from the total velocity of the system. Since the collisions are perfectly elastic, and the surface is frctionless, the total energy of the system remains constant, and there is no entropy.
Since the system starts with all of the energy oriented in one direction, and ends with all of the energy oriented in the other direction, this indicates a complete reversal of the energy of the system. Drawn in a circle with a radius of 1 around the origin, the starting point of the energy can be represented at (-1,0), and then the full reversal point at (1,0), creating a half circle. Each collision point in the diagram is represented in the semi-circle showing the energy levels via tangential lines. I believe that there are two objects doubles the semi-circle, since it is bouncing back and forth.
The path of collisions follows around the circle, representing the gradual reversal of the energy pointing from the first direction to the other direction., accurately representing pi.

I have an argument that it is π√m collisions, but it gets a bit hand wavy at the end.

Let x be the velocity of the large mass, y be the velocity of the small mass. Let the small mass be 1kg and large mass be m kg.

From conservation of energy:
1/2 mx^2 + 1/2y^2 = constant
or mx^2 + y^2 = constant

And from conservation of momentum,
mx + y = constant, whenever the two masses collide.

Let w = √m x. Then the equations transform into:
w^2 + y^2 = constant,
√m w + y = constant.

For simplicity assume the first constant is 1. Then the first equation says that throughout the whole interaction (w,y) will move between different points on the unit circle.
When the two blocks collide, the new values of (w,y) will also lie on the same line √m w + y = constant, which is a line with slope -√m.

So we can imagine the interaction as moving around a unit circle, starting at (1,0). We repeat the following alternating steps:
a) Move up and to the left at slope -√m until hitting the circle again. This is the blocks colliding.
b) Move directly down until hitting the circle again (resulting in y flipping to negative. This is the small block reflecting off the wall.

For m = 1 the slope is -1 and the path looks like:
(1,0) ->(step a, move at 45 degrees) -> (0,1) -> (step b, move down) -> (0,-1) -> (step a, move at 45 degrees) -> (-1,0).

As m becomes larger, we are zig zagging at a higher angle and getting more hits.
To finish the interaction, the path needs to travel 2 units down the horizontal w axis. But as the slope becomes larger, it needs to travel much more along the vertical y axis to complete that distance.
Total horizontal distance completed = 2,
Total vertical distance completed on (a) steps= 2√m, since the slope is -√m.
How much vertical distance does the average (a) step complete? For large m, it seems like it's the same as the average height of the circle, π/2.
But this is not the case, since the path will spend more time in low height areas, since it is making more hits there.
In an area near the center where the height is twice as large, the path will make half as many hits.
The average distance completed by an (a) step will be the weighted average height of the circle, weighted by 1/height
Note that height = 2y = 2√(1-w^2). So we will use the weight 1/√(1-w^2) and normalize the whole equation:

(w=0->1) ∫ 2√(1-w^2) * 1/√(1-w^2) dw
--------------------------------------------------------
(w=0->1) ∫ 1/√(1-w^2) dw

The top cancels out to 2.
For the bottom let cos (t) = w.

dw/dt = -sin(t) = -√(1-w^2)
so the bottom becomes
(t=π/2->0) ∫ 1/√(1-w^2) *-√(1-w^2) dt
=(t=π/2->0) ∫ -1 dt
=π/2.

And so the average vertical distance completed by an (a) step is 2/(π/2) = 4/π
Therefore there will be approximately 2√m / (4/π) = π√m / 2 (a) steps.
Therefore the total number of collisions will be twice that ( since we alternate (a) and (b) steps).
So the total number of collisions will be approximately π√m.

Many people already pointed out conservation of energy and momentum

First let's skip a lot of algebraic steps by referring to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elastic_collision
Let big mass be M and big mass's velocity be V, small mass be m and small mass's velocity be v
Then after a collision
v' = (m-M)/(m+M) * v + (2M)/(m+M) * V
V' = (2m)/(m+M) * v + (M-m)/(m+M) * V

To Simplify a bit, let M/m be the ratio R

v' = -(R-1)/(1+R) * v + (2R)/(1+R) * V
V' = 2/(1+R) * v + (R - 1)/(1+R) * V

To me this looks like a matrix, but I want a rotation matrix. Let x = sqrt(R)V

v' = -(R-1)/(1+R) * v + (2)/(1+R) * x * sqrt(R)
V' = 2/(1+R) * v + (R - 1)/(1+R) * V [ multiply both sides by sqrt(R)
x' = 2sqrt(R)/(1+R) * v + (R-1)/(1+R) * x

Now a collision causes x and v to evolve by a rotation matrix where one of the terms is (R-1)/(1+R) and the other term is 2sqrt(R)/(1+R). One will be A cos (theta) and the other will be A* sin(theta), where A is a scaling factor.

(R-1)^2 + (2sqrt(R))^2 = (R^2 - 2R + 1) + (4 R) = R^2 + 2R + 1 = (R+1)^2. Ok, I guess A =1. The angle can easily be calculated from the ratio. For now I'm just gonna take theta = arcsin(2sqrt(R)/(1+R)).

We want to solve for the # of collisions so that V changes sign but also so that V > v so that the smaller mass can never catch up and collide again. My physical intuition tells me that this will happen when the big mass is travelling very nearly at the speed V_0 but in the opposite direction, because otherwise there will be too much energy in the small mass which will catch up. For V0 to rotate to become -V0 we want a 180 degree rotation, so

N*theta = pi
N = pi/theta = pi/arcsin(2sqrt(R)/(1+R)).

Noting sin(x) ~ x for small x,
1+R ~ R for large R

N ~ pi * (1+R)/2sqrt(R) = pi * sqrt(R)/2.

To remove the factor of 2 note that each collision between the blocks also causes a collison with the wall.

N ~ pi * sqrt(R)

Another place where pi unexpectedly shows up, let's say two wealthy gamblers begin tossing fair coins, gaining 1 $ on heads and losing 1$ on tails. Both start at 0 and only stop tossing their respective coins when they reach 1$. Probability they will reach their targets on the same toss is 4/pi-1. In fact, any such game you construct will take the form, A/pi+B. See: https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/3058952/using-a-gamblers-race-to-approximate-pi

Here are the solution and thought process based on the animation at 4:36. Upon first look, it seems to be a dot bouncing on a 2-d plane, but the problem is 1-d, so what are the x and y-axis representing? A reasonable guess would be they are the location of the two cubes respectively. Then the collision would be when the two cubes reach the same location, x=y, However, the angle shown in the animation is much smaller than 45 deg.

Considering we are using conservation of energy as the basis of the collision, plot the x and y-axis as the location times the square root of the mass of each cube instead - sqrt(m)*d. In that case, the collision would be happening at where d1=d2, which means y/sqrt(m1)=x/sqrt(m2). That would be the slanted line shown in the animation. In this case, the speed of the dot in x and y directions would then be the speed of the cubes times the sqrt of the mass. Thus the norm of this vector would be (twice) the total kinetic energy of both cubes. Since energy is conserved in each collision, the norm of the velocity vector must be constant.

When the smaller cube collides with the wall, it would reverse speed while the bigger cube is unaffected. It would seem like the dot bounced off the x-axis in the planed we constructed. A collision of the cubes is constituted by two principles: conservation of energy and conservation of momentum. Conservation of energy means the speed of the dot is constant. Conservation of momentum means m1*v1+m2*v2 is constant. Considering the way we are plotting the plane, it means that sqrt(m1)*v_y+sqrt(m2)*v_x is constant. We can write that in vector product form: (sqrt(m1),sqrt(m2))*(v_y,v_x). So the projection of the speed onto the slanted line is also constant. That can only mean that the velocity is deflected on the line. (Actually, there are two possible solutions, the other being that the velocity did not change. A quick sanity check tells us the cubes did not phase through each other, so that's not an actual solution.

Now that we've established the collision of two cubes in 1-d can be represented by the collision of one dot in 2-d. The rest is to just unfold the movement based on symmetry. That would look like the dot that's moving in a straight line in the animation. The angle of the line is arctan(sqrt(m1/m2)). When m1 is much smaller than m2, that just approaches sqrt(m1/m2). So the number of collisions is pi/sqrt(m1/m2).

I couldn't figure out the math. So I did the next best thing, I programmed it!
Here is my Python (3.x) code (with comments):

# u1 = speed before collision of the big block
# u2 = speed before collision of the small block
# v1 = speed after collision of the big block
# v2 = speed after collision of the small block

# Desired number of digits of pi
ndigits = 3

# Masses of the blocks
m1 = 100 ** (ndigits - 1)
m2 = 1

u1 = 1 # Result is independent of this value
u2 = 0

# print(u1, u2)
collision_count = 0

while u1 > u2:

# Collision happens. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elastic_collision#One-dimensional_Newtonian for the math behind this
frac = m1 + m2
v1 = (m1 - m2) / frac * u1 + 2 * m2 / frac * u2
v2 = (m2 - m1) / frac * u2 + 2 * m1 / frac * u1

# After the blocks collide, the small block also collides with the wall, so add 2 collisions.
collision_count += 2

# The velocity of the big block remains the same. The velocity of the small block gets reversed (because the small block hits the wall)
u1 = v1
u2 = -v2
# print(u1, u2)


# If v2 is negative, then the small block does not reach the wall again, so remove a collision. (See ~2:10)
if v2 < 0:
collision_count -= 1

print(collision_count)

I fiddled around a bit with some examples and then just did the general case of M = x * m
What I found out is that no matter what, the velocity after a collision for the blocks for
Block 1: v1' = 2x/(1+x) v2 - v1
Block 2: v2' = 2x/(1+x) v2 - v2
if we then substitute 2x/(1+x) with k we get
v1' = k v2 - v1
v2' = k v2 - v2

Let the big block have mass n^2.
Draw a plane where
x =n*(speed of big block)
y=speed of small block
x^2+y^2=2*(total energy)
as total energy is conserved, system is constrained to circle.
Blocks colliding preserves momentum, equiv to mirroring by line y=x/n
Small block on wall is mirror by line y=0
As n large, get zigzag across circle, like tacking up wind on circular lake.
As chords of circle have same angle with any other point of circle, each zigzag moves the same dist around circle.
This dist is approx 1/n, so getting right round circle takes ~Pi bounces.

Not an actual solution but two things which could relate π and this.

1. As energy is conserved, ½mu²+½Mv²=constant, this is similar to the equation of an ellipse (x/a)²+(y/b)²=1.
(Sure, it's not a circle but π does show up in the case of ellipse as well. Alternately, maybe it could be smartly translated to be a circle by scaling one axis.)

2. The fact that the ratio of masses is 10^(d-1) is not THAT arbitrary considering how 3.1415... is the expansion of π in base *10*.
